elements.content: Five new silver(I) double and triple salts containing conformationally flexible 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide (−CCCH2CH2CC–, C6H4 2–) and nitrate ions, namely Ag2C6H4 ·7AgNO3 (1), Ag2C6H4 ·3AgNO3 ·2AgF (2), Ag2C6H4 ·4AgNO3 ·2L1 (3; L1 = imidazole), Ag2C6H4 ·2AgNO3 ·2AgL2 (4; HL2 = pyrazole), and Ag2C6H4 ·4AgNO3 ·2L3 (5; L3 = 3,5-dimethylpyrazole), have been synthesized, in which the C6H4 2– species was found to adopt two distinct configurations: anti in 1 and 3 and gauche in 2, 4, and 5. Complex 1 features an unusual Ag5⊂C6H4⊃Ag4 aggregate as the basic building unit, and such aggregates are interconnected by the nitrate ions to generate a three-dimensional coordination network. Complex 2 exhibits a three-dimensional coordination network constructed with compact C6H4⊃Ag7 units, nitrate ions, and fluoride ions that assume a μ3 trigonal-pyramidal coordination mode. In 3, the Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag4 aggregates are stabilized by nitrate groups and imidazole ligands to generate a layer structure. In complex 4, infinite chains each bearing deprotonated pyrazole ligands attached to the silver backbone are weaved by nitrate groups to form a three-dimensional coordination architecture. In 5 the 3,5-dimethylpyrazole ligands coordinate to silver atoms at the upper surface of each coordination layer, and the layers are interconnected to form a three-dimensional supramolecular network via hydrogen bonding.

Complex 1 features an unusual Ag5⊂C6H4⊃Ag4 aggregate as the basic building unit, and such aggregates are interconnected by the nitrate ions to generate a three-dimensional coordination network. Complex 2 exhibits a three-dimensional coordination network constructed with compact C6H4⊃Ag7 units, nitrate ions, and fluoride ions that assume a μ3 trigonal-pyramidal coordination mode. In 3, the Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag4 aggregates are stabilized by nitrate groups and imidazole ligands to generate a layer structure. elements.content: In recent years, metal complexes of polyyne ligands have continued to attract much attention due to their potential application as precursors or model compounds of electrical conductors, rigid-rod molecular wires, and nonlinear optical materials. In particular, intense investigation has focused on the exploration and exploitation of this class of compounds as luminescent materials. Coordination of ethynide ligands to transition-metal centers via σ/π bonding modes and metallophilic interactions can combine to form metal clusters and cages. Recent studies have demonstrated that rich photoluminescent properties are generated from different types of charge-transfer transitions between metal–carbon and metal–metal bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, metal complexes of polyyne ligands have continued to attract much attention due to their potential application as precursors or model compounds of electrical conductors, rigid-rod molecular wires, and nonlinear optical materials. In particular, intense investigation has focused on the exploration and exploitation of this class of compounds as luminescent materials. Coordination of ethynide ligands to transition-metal centers via σ/π bonding modes and metallophilic interactions can combine to form metal clusters and cages. Recent studies have demonstrated that rich photoluminescent properties are generated from different types of charge-transfer transitions between metal-carbon and metal-metal bonds.

elements.content: For well over a decade, our systematic investigation on the synthesis and structural characterization of the double and multiple salts of silver acetylide (silver ethynediide, Ag2C2) has demonstrated that the C2 2– dianion is invariably encapsulated inside a polyhedral Ag n cage (n = 6–10), the shape of which can be affected by coexisting anions, cations, polyoxoanions, and neutral solvate molecules. The introduction of bridging nitrogen-donor ligands between such C2@Ag n units has led to a rich variety of discrete molecular, 1D, 2D, and 3D crystal structures. Correspondingly, a series of silver complexes of 1,3-butadiyne-1,4-diide (−CCCC–, C4 2–) has also been synthesized, and diverse configurations of the Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag4 multinuclear supramolecular synthon are observed in the presence of different anions and ancillary ligands.
elements.clean_text: For well over a decade, our systematic investigation on the synthesis and structural characterization of the double and multiple salts of silver acetylide (silver ethynediide, Ag2C2) has demonstrated that the C2 2- dianion is invariably encapsulated inside a polyhedral Ag n  cage (n = 6-10), the shape of which can be affected by coexisting anions, cations, polyoxoanions, and neutral solvate molecules. The introduction of bridging nitrogen-donor ligands between such C2@Ag n  units has led to a rich variety of discrete molecular, 1D, 2D, and 3D crystal structures. Correspondingly, a series of silver complexes of 1,3-butadiyne-1,4-diide (-CCCC-, C4 2-) has also been synthesized, and diverse configurations of the Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag4 multinuclear supramolecular synthon are observed in the presence of different anions and ancillary ligands.

elements.content: In order to explore new kinds of multinuclear supramolecular synthons in the silver ethynide system, we decided to conduct a systematic study on silver complexes containing 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide (−CCCH2CH2CC–, C6H4 2–), which has two terminal ethynide groups connected by a flexible dimethylene backbone. In the present work, we report the synthesis and structural characterization of the following five complexes: Ag2C6H4·7AgNO3 (1), Ag2C6H4·3AgNO3·2AgF (2), Ag2C6H4·4AgNO3·2L1 (3; L1 = imidazole), Ag2C6H4·2AgNO3·2AgL2 (4; HL2 = pyrazole), and Ag2C6H4·4AgNO3·2L3 (5; L3 = 3,5-dimethylpyrazole).
elements.clean_text: In order to explore new kinds of multinuclear supramolecular synthons in the silver ethynide system, we decided to conduct a systematic study on silver complexes containing 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide (-CCCH2CH2CC-, C6H4 2-), which has two terminal ethynide groups connected by a flexible dimethylene backbone. In the present work, we report the synthesis and structural characterization of the following five complexes: Ag2C6H4⋅7AgNO3 (1), Ag2C6H4⋅3AgNO3⋅2AgF (2), Ag2C6H4⋅4AgNO3⋅2L1 (3; L1 = imidazole), Ag2C6H4⋅2AgNO3⋅2AgL2 (4; HL2 = pyrazole), and Ag2C6H4⋅4AgNO3⋅2L3 (5; L3 = 3,5-dimethylpyrazole).

elements.content: The starting material [AgCCCH2CH2CCAg] n has been synthesized for the first time by reacting 1,5-hexadiyne with silver nitrate in acetonitrile. The synthetic procedure is based on the fact that silver ethynide complexes have poor solubility in common solvents and can be easily separated by precipitation. The crude polymeric compound [AgCCCH2CH2CCAg] n can be dissolved in a concentrated aqueous solution of silver ions to form Ag n ⊂CCCH2CH2CC⊃Ag m moieties consolidated by argentophilic interactions. Complexes 1 and 2 were obtained by crystallization of [AgCCCH2CH2CCAg] n in a concentrated aqueous solution of AgNO3 or a mixed aqueous solution of AgNO3 and AgF. Compounds 3–5 were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions using [AgCCCH2CH2CCAg] n dissolved in a concentrated solution of silver nitrate, together with the addition of different nitrogen heteroaromatic compounds as ancillary donor ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The starting material [AgCCCH2CH2CCAg] n  has been synthesized for the first time by reacting 1,5-hexadiyne with silver nitrate in acetonitrile. The synthetic procedure is based on the fact that silver ethynide complexes have poor solubility in common solvents and can be easily separated by precipitation. The crude polymeric compound [AgCCCH2CH2CCAg] n  can be dissolved in a concentrated aqueous solution of silver ions to form Ag n ⊂CCCH2CH2CC⊃Ag m  moieties consolidated by argentophilic interactions. Complexes 1 and 2 were obtained by crystallization of [AgCCCH2CH2CCAg] n  in a concentrated aqueous solution of AgNO3 or a mixed aqueous solution of AgNO3 and AgF. Compounds 3-5 were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions using [AgCCCH2CH2CCAg] n  dissolved in a concentrated solution of silver nitrate, together with the addition of different nitrogen heteroaromatic compounds as ancillary donor ligands.

elements.content: In the crystal structure of compound 1, the asymmetric unit contains a Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag5 aggregate and seven independent nitrate groups. The C6H4 2– ion (C1C2–C3–C4–C5C6) taking the anti “stretched-Z” conformation adopts an unusual μ9 coordination mode and is sandwiched between a Ag5 square pyramid (composed of atoms Ag1–Ag5) and a distorted Ag4 trigonal pyramid (atoms Ag6–Ag9) (Figure a). One terminal ethynide, C1C2, is inserted into the square-pyramidal Ag5 pocket to form a σ-type silver–ethynide bond (Ag2–C1 = 2.090(2) Å), three σ/π-type silver–ethynide bonds with bond lengths in the range 2.278(2)–2.378(2) Å, and a π bond (Ag4–C2 = 2.697(1) Å). The other terminal ethynide, C5C6, attaches to the Ag4 trigonal pyramid through three Ag–C σ/π bonds with bond lengths in the range 2.177(2)–2.320(2) Å and a π bond (Ag9–C5 = 2.576(1) Å). The independent nitrate groups, which may be conveniently referred to by naming their nitrogen atoms N1–N7 (Figure a), adopt different coordination modes to connect with the Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag5 unit: μ3-O,O′,O″ plus O,O′-chelating mode for N1 and N3, μ2-O,O′ mode for N2, μ4-O,O′,O″ for N4, μ3-O,O′ for N5, μ2-O,O′ plus O,O″-chelating mode for N6, and μ2-O,O′ for N7. The Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag5 aggregates arranged in a pseudohexagonal array (Figure b) are linked by the nitrate groups to form a three-dimensional coordination network (Figure b,c).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

Ag2C6H4 ⋅7AgNO3 (1)

In the crystal structure of compound 1, the asymmetric unit contains a Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag5 aggregate and seven independent nitrate groups. The C6H4 2- ion (C1C2-C3-C4-C5C6) taking the anti "stretched-Z" conformation adopts an unusual μ9 coordination mode and is sandwiched between a Ag5 square pyramid (composed of atoms Ag1-Ag5) and a distorted Ag4 trigonal pyramid (atoms Ag6-Ag9) (Figure a). One terminal ethynide, C1C2, is inserted into the square-pyramidal Ag5 pocket to form a σ-type silver-ethynide bond (Ag2-C1 = 2.090(2) Å), three σ/π-type silver-ethynide bonds with bond lengths in the range 2.278(2)-2.378(2) Å, and a π bond (Ag4-C2 = 2.697(1) Å). The other terminal ethynide, C5C6, attaches to the Ag4 trigonal pyramid through three Ag-C σ/π bonds with bond lengths in the range 2.177(2)-2.320(2) Å and a π bond (Ag9-C5 = 2.576(1) Å). The independent nitrate groups, which may be conveniently referred to by naming their nitrogen atoms N1-N7 (Figure a), adopt different coordination modes to connect with the Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag5 unit: μ3-O,O',O" plus O,O'-chelating mode for N1 and N3, μ2-O,O' mode for N2, μ4-O,O',O" for N4, μ3-O,O' for N5, μ2-O,O' plus O,O"-chelating mode for N6, and μ2-O,O' for N7. The Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag5 aggregates arranged in a pseudohexagonal array (Figure b) are linked by the nitrate groups to form a three-dimensional coordination network (Figure b,c).

elements.content: In compound 2, the C6H4 2– dianion takes the gauche conformation to adopt the μ8 coordination mode, being embraced by a Ag7 basket (defined by Ag1–Ag7). The C6H4 2– dianion is shaped like a twisted arch bridge, with its ethynide terminals C1C2 and C5C6 bound to the Ag7 basket though silver–ethynide Ag···C σ, mixed (σ, π), and π bonds: σ-type Ag3–C1 = 2.065(9), Ag6–C6 = 2.078(9) Å; four σ/π type in the range 2.354(1)–2.708(1) Å; π-type Ag1–C2 = 2.543(1), Ag7–C5 = 2.471(1) Å (Figure a). In the asymmetric unit, three independent nitrate groups adopt different coordination modes (μ2 for N1, μ2 for N2, and μ5 for N3), and two independent fluoride ions are each strongly bonded to three silver atoms with Ag–F distances in the range 2.104(6)–2.556(7) Ǻ (Figure a). Silver complexes containing a μ3-F ligand are quite rare, and to our knowledge there are only four literature examples of such compounds: [(Ag2C2)(AgF)(AgCF3SO3)4(CH3CN)], [(Ag2C2)(AgF)(AgCF3SO3)4(C2H5CN)], [(C72H48Ag6FN12)(BF4)5·11H2O], and [(Ag2C4)2(AgF)2(AgNO3)6(H2O)]. The trigonal-pyramidal ligation mode of μ3-F in compound 2 is similar to that in [(Ag2C4)2(AgF)2(AgNO3)6(H2O)], but it differs from the planar μ3 mode in the other three complexes. The C6H4⊃Ag7 aggregates related by the a translation are connected (Ag6···Ag3d, Ag6···Ag2d, Ag7···Ag2d) to form an infinite silver chain, and such chains are further cross-linked across inversion centers (Ag1···Ag3a, Ag3···Ag1a) to yield an argentophilic layer parallel to the ab plane, which is further stabilized by bridging nitrate groups (N2 and N3) (Figure b). Interlayer linkage by bridging nitrate groups (N1) and fluoride ions (F1) then yields a structurally robust 3D coordination network (Figure c).

elements.content: The crystal structure of compound 3 contains two independent centrosymmetric Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag4 aggregates, as shown in Figure a. The first C6H4 2– dianion (C1C2–C3–C3a–C2aC1a) taking the anti conformation has each terminus capped by a butterfly-shaped Ag4 basket (defined by Ag1–Ag4), which is similar to that observed in silver 1,3-butadiyne-1,4-diyl complexes. The terminal ethynide, C1C2, bonds to the Ag4 basket via a μ4-η1:η1:η2:η2 mode, with a Ag···C σ bond (Ag2–C1 = 2.108(1) Ǻ) and three σ/π-type bonds with bond lengths in the range 2.255(1)–2.386(1) Ǻ. In the other C6H4 2– dianion, the terminal ethynide C6C5 is similarly wrapped up by a Ag4 basket through mix σ/π silver–ethynide interactions, with bonds length in the range 2.096(1)–2.365(1) Ǻ. The two kinds of Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag4 aggregates coalesce together by sharing silver atoms of type Ag4 and Ag3b to form an infinite argentophilic chain in the direction of the a axis, additional stability being provided by bridging nitrate groups (μ2-O,O coordination mode for N1, μ2-O,O′ for N2). In the silver skeleton, Ag2 and Ag5 are each coordinated by an imidazole ligand (N5 and N7, respectively), Ag1 is coordinated by O atoms from three nitrate ligands (N1–N3), and Ag6 is likewise coordinated by three nitrate groups (N4, N2g, and N1h) (Figure a). The Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag4 aggregates are fused together with linkage of nitrate groups to form a two-dimensional coordination network parallel to the ab plane (Figure b). Weak imidazole N–H···Onitrate hydrogen bonds exist between adjacent coordination layers (Figure c), thus generating a three-dimensional supramolecular framework.

elements.content: As in compounds 2, the C6H4 2– dianion of the C6H4⊃Ag7 aggregate in 4 also takes the gauche conformation to adopt a μ7 ligating mode (Figure a). One terminal ethynide, C1C2, bonds to a Ag4 basket via the μ4-η1:η1:η1:η2 mode, with Ag···C σ/π bonds in the range 2.136(9)–2.370(9) Ǻ and a Ag1–C2 π bond of length 2.616(9) Ǻ. The other terminal ethynide, C5C6, bonds to a Ag4 basket in a similar manner, with Ag···C σ/π bonds in the range 2.147(1)–2.384(9) Ǻ and a Ag1–C5 π bond length of 2.548(1) Ǻ. Adjacent C6H4⊃Ag7 aggregates are fused together to yield an infinite silver chain by sharing type Ag3 atoms (Figure b). The silver chain is stabilized by pyrazolate ligands and N2 nitrate groups on the opposite side of the C6H4 2– ligands. The silver chains are further linked by N1 nitrate groups (defined by N1, O1, O2, and O3, adopting the μ4 coordination mode to form a 2D coordination network parallel to the bc plane (Figure c). Finally, adjacent silver layers are linked by pillarlike N2 nitrate groups (defined by N2, O4, O5, and O6, adopting the μ2 coordination mode) to form a 3D coordination framework (Figure d).

Ag2C6H4 ⋅2AgNO3 ⋅2AgL2 (4; HL2 = Pyrazole)

As in compounds 2, the C6H4 2- dianion of the C6H4⊃Ag7 aggregate in 4 also takes the gauche conformation to adopt a μ7 ligating mode (Figure a). One terminal ethynide, C1C2, bonds to a Ag4 basket via the μ4-η1:η1:η1:η2 mode, with Ag⋅⋅⋅C σ/π bonds in the range 2.136(9)-2.370(9) Ǻ and a Ag1-C2 π bond of length 2.616(9) Ǻ. The other terminal ethynide, C5C6, bonds to a Ag4 basket in a similar manner, with Ag⋅⋅⋅C σ/π bonds in the range 2.147(1)-2.384(9) Ǻ and a Ag1-C5 π bond length of 2.548(1) Ǻ. Adjacent C6H4⊃Ag7 aggregates are fused together to yield an infinite silver chain by sharing type Ag3 atoms (Figure b). The silver chain is stabilized by pyrazolate ligands and N2 nitrate groups on the opposite side of the C6H4 2- ligands. The silver chains are further linked by N1 nitrate groups (defined by N1, O1, O2, and O3, adopting the μ4 coordination mode to form a 2D coordination network parallel to the bc plane (Figure c). Finally, adjacent silver layers are linked by pillarlike N2 nitrate groups (defined by N2, O4, O5, and O6, adopting the μ2 coordination mode) to form a 3D coordination framework (Figure d).

elements.content: In the crystal structure of 5, the gauche C6H4 2– dianion lies on a crystallographic 2-fold axis (Figure a). The terminal ethynide C1C2 bonds to a Ag4 basket via the μ4-η1:η2:η2:η2 mode, forming a Ag···C σ bond (Ag3–C1 = 2.073(7) Ǻ), a σ/π bond (Ag2–C1 = 2.317(7) Ǻ) and two π bonds (Ag1–C1 = 2.277(7) Å; Ag4–C1 = 2.503(8) Ǻ). In addition to the C6H4⊃Ag7 aggregate, the asymmetric unit contains a 3,5-dimethylpyrazole ligand (bonded to Ag3) and two independent nitrate groups, which may be conveniently referred to by naming their nitrogen atoms. The C6H4⊃Ag7 aggregates fuse into a zigzag silver chain along the a axis by sharing Ag2 atoms. Adjacent silver chains are further cross-linked by nitrate groups (N1 acting in the μ2-O,O mode and N2 acting in the μ2-O,O′ coordination mode, respectively) to form a coordination layer parallel to the ab plane (Figure b). Weak CL3–H···Onitrate hydrogen bonds between the L3 ligand and nitrate groups exist between adjacent coordination layers (Figure c), thus generating a three-dimensional supramolecular framework.

elements.content: Two distinct coordination modes of the C6H4 2– dianions within the five new silver(I) double and triple salts are shown in Figure . The C6H4 2– dianion exhibits a “stretched-Z” configuration in 1 and 3 and an “archlike” configuration in 2, 4, and 5; with reference to the torsion angle about the dimethylene backbone, these two configurations can be designated as anti (1, 3) and gauche (2, 4, 5), respectively. In 1, the ethynide groups are capped by a Ag5 square pyramid at one end and a Ag4 trigonal pyramid at the other. In 3, both terminal ethynide groups are capped by a Ag4 trigonal pyramid. In 2, 4, and 5, the C6H4 2– dianoins are each half-wrapped by a Ag7 aggregate, and such silver aggregates take bowllike (2), boatlike (4), and butterfly knot (5) shapes, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Coordination Modes of C6H4 2- 

Two distinct coordination modes of the C6H4 2- dianions within the five new silver(I) double and triple salts are shown in Figure . The C6H4 2- dianion exhibits a "stretched-Z" configuration in 1 and 3 and an "archlike" configuration in 2, 4, and 5; with reference to the torsion angle about the dimethylene backbone, these two configurations can be designated as anti (1, 3) and gauche (2, 4, 5), respectively. In 1, the ethynide groups are capped by a Ag5 square pyramid at one end and a Ag4 trigonal pyramid at the other. In 3, both terminal ethynide groups are capped by a Ag4 trigonal pyramid. In 2, 4, and 5, the C6H4 2- dianoins are each half-wrapped by a Ag7 aggregate, and such silver aggregates take bowllike (2), boatlike (4), and butterfly knot (5) shapes, respectively.

elements.content: The variation in shape of the Ag n aggregates in complexes 1–5 may be ascribed to diverse silver–ethynide bonding interactions resulting from the μ n coordination mode of each terminal CC unit in the C6H4 2– ligand. The silver–ethynide interactions in these complexes can be broadly classified into three types: σ, π, and mixed (σ,π), according to criteria based on the observed Ag–C bond distances and CC–Ag bond angles. As listed in Table S1 (), the measured σ, π and mixed (σ,π) Ag–C bond distances in complexes 1–5 lie in the ranges 2.065(9)–2.108(1), 2.267(9)–2.503(8), and 2.096(1)–2.708(1) Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Argentophilic Interaction and Silver-Ethynide Bonding

The variation in shape of the Ag n  aggregates in complexes 1-5 may be ascribed to diverse silver-ethynide bonding interactions resulting from the μ n  coordination mode of each terminal CC unit in the C6H4 2- ligand. The silver-ethynide interactions in these complexes can be broadly classified into three types: σ, π, and mixed (σ,π), according to criteria based on the observed Ag-C bond distances and CC-Ag bond angles. As listed in Table S1 (), the measured σ, π and mixed (σ,π) Ag-C bond distances in complexes 1-5 lie in the ranges 2.065(9)-2.108(1), 2.267(9)-2.503(8), and 2.096(1)-2.708(1) Å, respectively.

elements.content: By analogy with Ag2C2 and Ag2C4, crude Ag2C6H4 readily dissolves in a concentrated aqueous solution containing silver(I) ions to form labile [C6H4@Ag n ] species. Our conceived strategy was to neutralize and stabilize the [C6H4@Ag n ] species by suitable anionic ligands and subsequently optimize the conditions of crystallization to obtain double and multiple silver complexes of 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide, C6H4 2–. However, dissolution of Ag2C6H4 in a concentrated aqueous solution containing one or more of the inorganic silver salts AgNO3, AgF, AgBF4, AgClO4, and AgPF6 only led to successful crystallization of compounds 1 and 2. Bearing in mind that, in our previous work, selected nitrogen-donor ligands had been successfully incorporated as ancillary ligands to generate crystalline compounds that exhibit discrete molecular, 1D, 2D, and 3D structures, we tried to introduce various nitrogen-donor ligands into the 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide/silver nitrate system. Most attempts were unsuccessful, and the failed cases included pyrazine, 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane, 4,4′-bipyridine, 2,2′-bipyridine, 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane, 4-pyridinecarboxylic acid, pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid, 1,2,4-triazole, benzimidazole, 4-cyanopyridine, 1,4-dicyanobenzene, and 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid. Only three heteroaromatic ligands, namely imidazole, pyrazole, and 3,5-dimethylpyrazole, could be successfully incorporated into the 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide/silver nitrate system. The reason for the failed cases is not clear, but a plausible explanation is that those nitrogen-donor ligands with relatively larger steric bulk may be detrimental to the onset of argentophilic interactions, which provides the driving force to transform polymeric Ag2C6H4 to labile [C6H4@Ag n ] species in the 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide/silver nitrate system.
elements.clean_text:
Role of Coexisting Inorganic Anions and Nitrogen-Donor Ligands

By analogy with Ag2C2 and Ag2C4, crude Ag2C6H4 readily dissolves in a concentrated aqueous solution containing silver(I) ions to form labile [C6H4@Ag n ] species. Our conceived strategy was to neutralize and stabilize the [C6H4@Ag n ] species by suitable anionic ligands and subsequently optimize the conditions of crystallization to obtain double and multiple silver complexes of 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide, C6H4 2-. However, dissolution of Ag2C6H4 in a concentrated aqueous solution containing one or more of the inorganic silver salts AgNO3, AgF, AgBF4, AgClO4, and AgPF6 only led to successful crystallization of compounds 1 and 2. Bearing in mind that, in our previous work, selected nitrogen-donor ligands had been successfully incorporated as ancillary ligands to generate crystalline compounds that exhibit discrete molecular, 1D, 2D, and 3D structures, we tried to introduce various nitrogen-donor ligands into the 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide/silver nitrate system. Most attempts were unsuccessful, and the failed cases included pyrazine, 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane, 4,4'-bipyridine, 2,2'-bipyridine, 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane, 4-pyridinecarboxylic acid, pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid, 1,2,4-triazole, benzimidazole, 4-cyanopyridine, 1,4-dicyanobenzene, and 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid. Only three heteroaromatic ligands, namely imidazole, pyrazole, and 3,5-dimethylpyrazole, could be successfully incorporated into the 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide/silver nitrate system. The reason for the failed cases is not clear, but a plausible explanation is that those nitrogen-donor ligands with relatively larger steric bulk may be detrimental to the onset of argentophilic interactions, which provides the driving force to transform polymeric Ag2C6H4 to labile [C6H4@Ag n ] species in the 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide/silver nitrate system.

elements.content: There are precedents of pyrazolate acting as an exogenous μ2 ligand in the literature: for example, in the syntheses and characterization of polymeric [Ag(pz)] n and trimeric [Ag(μ2-pz)]3, the dinuclear [(η5-C5Me5)2Rh2(μ2-pz)(μ-SC6H5)2]+ cation, and the octanuclear [Ni8(μ4-OH)6(μ2-pz)12]2– cube. Notably, pyrazole undergoes deprotonation to bridge a pair of silver atoms in complex 4, whereas imidazole and 3,5-dimethylpyrazole function as neutral monodentate ligands in 3 and 5, respectively. This difference in ligand behavior may be rationalized by noting that each of the two independent pyrazolate ligands in 4 bridges a pair of adjacent silver atoms (Figure b), thereby playing a crucial role in the generation of an infinite silver chain stabilized by argentophilic interactions. If 3,5-dimethylpyrazolate were formed, it could not be similarly densely bound to the silver chain in view of the steric bulk of its methyl substituents; in the case of imidazole, its deprotonated form obviously cannot function in an exo-bidentate bridging mode.

elements.content: In summary, we have structurally characterized five new silver(I) nitrate complexes containing the 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide dianion with ancillary heteroaromatic N-donor ligands. Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized in solution and crystallized by slow evaporation, whereas 3–5 were synthesized through the hydrothermal method. Diverse Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag n (n = 4, 5) and C6H4⊃Ag7 aggregates were observed, in which the C6H4 2– dianions were found to adopt two distinct configurations, anti and gauche, respectively, in their coordination to multiple silver(I) centers. These configurations can be tuned by varying the ancillary anionic ligands and N-donor ligands, as well as the stoichiometric ratio. The trigonal-pyramidal coordination mode of the μ3-F ligand in compound 2 is uncommon among silver(I) complexes. In 3–5, heteroaromatic N-donor ligands are introduced into the silver 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide/silver nitrate system to obtain different dimensional networks assembled with the Ag n ⊂C6H4 supramolecular synthon. Compounds 3 and 5 exhibit two-dimensional coordination networks, wherein the N-donor ligands attached to the silver skeleton serve as terminal stoppers to prevent further connection between stacked layers to attain higher dimensionality. The present study has demonstrated that a variety of different dimensional structures can be constructed by linking the Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag n and C6H4⊃Ag7 supramolecular synthons with mono- or bidentate nitrogen-donor ligands, thereby opening the gate to future construction of silver-organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have structurally characterized five new silver(I) nitrate complexes containing the 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide dianion with ancillary heteroaromatic N-donor ligands. Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized in solution and crystallized by slow evaporation, whereas 3-5 were synthesized through the hydrothermal method. Diverse Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag n  (n = 4, 5) and C6H4⊃Ag7 aggregates were observed, in which the C6H4 2- dianions were found to adopt two distinct configurations, anti and gauche, respectively, in their coordination to multiple silver(I) centers. These configurations can be tuned by varying the ancillary anionic ligands and N-donor ligands, as well as the stoichiometric ratio. The trigonal-pyramidal coordination mode of the μ3-F ligand in compound 2 is uncommon among silver(I) complexes. In 3-5, heteroaromatic N-donor ligands are introduced into the silver 1,5-hexadiyne-1,6-diide/silver nitrate system to obtain different dimensional networks assembled with the Ag n ⊂C6H4 supramolecular synthon. Compounds 3 and 5 exhibit two-dimensional coordination networks, wherein the N-donor ligands attached to the silver skeleton serve as terminal stoppers to prevent further connection between stacked layers to attain higher dimensionality. The present study has demonstrated that a variety of different dimensional structures can be constructed by linking the Ag4⊂C6H4⊃Ag n  and C6H4⊃Ag7 supramolecular synthons with mono- or bidentate nitrogen-donor ligands, thereby opening the gate to future construction of silver-organic frameworks.

elements.content: All chemicals obtained from commercial sources were of analytically pure grade and were used without further purification: silver nitrate (RFCL, 99.9%), 1,5-hexadiyne (Alfa Aesar, 50% in pentane), silver fluoride (Acros, 99%), imidazole (BDH, 99%), pyrazole (Acros, 98%), 3,5-dimethylpyrazole (Aldrich, 99%), and acetonitrile (Scharlau, 99.9%). IR spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Nicolet Impact 420 FTIR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 with a resolution of 2 cm–1. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was performed by the Analysis and Testing Center of Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Melting points (uncorrected) were measured with a Reichert apparatus in degrees Celsius.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents and Instruments

All chemicals obtained from commercial sources were of analytically pure grade and were used without further purification: silver nitrate (RFCL, 99.9%), 1,5-hexadiyne (Alfa Aesar, 50% in pentane), silver fluoride (Acros, 99%), imidazole (BDH, 99%), pyrazole (Acros, 98%), 3,5-dimethylpyrazole (Aldrich, 99%), and acetonitrile (Scharlau, 99.9%). IR spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Nicolet Impact 420 FTIR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 with a resolution of 2 cm-1. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was performed by the Analysis and Testing Center of Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Melting points (uncorrected) were measured with a Reichert apparatus in degrees Celsius.

elements.content:
Caution! Silver ethynide complexes are potentially explosive and should be handled in small amounts with extreme care.

[AgCCCH<sub>2</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>CCAg]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>

The title compound is hereafter abbreviated as Ag2C6H4. Silver nitrate (0.680 g, 4 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of acetonitrile. Then 1,5-hexadiyne (0.156, 2 mmol) was added with vigorous stirring for 1 h. The white precipitate tha tformed was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with 3 × 10 mL of acetonitrile and 3 × 10 mL of deionized water to remove traces of nitric acid, and stored in a wet form for safety reasons. Yield: 0.478 g (82%).

elements.content: Moist Ag2C6H4 (∼100 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgNO3 (0.44 g, 2 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution reached saturation. The excess Ag2C6H4 was filtered off, and the solution was then placed in the dark at room temperature. After a few days, transparent colorless sheetlike crystals of 1 (∼75%) were deposited and collected. Compound 1 decomposes above 185 °C. IR: ν 2091 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C6H4Ag9N7O21 (M r = 1480.99): C, 4.87; H, 0.27, N; 6.62. Found: C, 4.51; H, 0.54; N, 6.48.

elements.content: Moist Ag2C6H4 (∼100 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgNO3 (0.44 g, 2 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution reached saturation. The excess Ag2C6H4 was filtered off, and then imidazole (40 mg) was added to the filtrate. The resulted suspension was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reaction vessel, subjected to hydrothermal conditions at 80 °C for 36 h, and subsequently cooled to room temperature at 5 °C/h. Colorless blocklike crystals of 3 were isolated in 65% yield. Compound 3 decomposes above 190 °C. IR: ν 2095 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C12H12Ag6N8O12 (M r = 1107.52): C, 13.01; H, 1.09; N, 10.12. Found: C, 13.12; H, 1.11; N, 10.24.

elements.content: Crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. The intensities were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by the multiscan method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 using the SHELX-97 program, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. For 4, oxygen atom O2 is disordered over two positions and was refined with an assigned site-occupancy ratio of 0.5:0.5. The NH groups of both independent pyrazole ligands in compound 4 are deprotonated in accordance with the requirement of charge balance. The crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1–5 are given in Table S2 ().
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. The intensities were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by the multiscan method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 using the SHELX-97 program, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. For 4, oxygen atom O2 is disordered over two positions and was refined with an assigned site-occupancy ratio of 0.5:0.5. The NH groups of both independent pyrazole ligands in compound 4 are deprotonated in accordance with the requirement of charge balance. The crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1-5 are given in Table S2 ().

elements.content:
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

In our working model, the terminal carbon atom bearing the negative charge draws neighboring Ag(I) atoms together to facilitate the onset of argentophilic interactions, such that the multinuclear silver–ethynide binding interaction is considered to be mainly ionic with minor covalent σ and π components. Therefore, the designation of “silver–ethynide bonds” of σ or mixed (σ,π) type should not be taken as normal covalent or coordination bonds.

References

In our working model, the terminal carbon atom bearing the negative charge draws neighboring Ag(I) atoms together to facilitate the onset of argentophilic interactions, such that the multinuclear silver-ethynide binding interaction is considered to be mainly ionic with minor covalent σ and π components. Therefore, the designation of "silver-ethynide bonds" of σ or mixed (σ,π) type should not be taken as normal covalent or coordination bonds.

elements.content: In general, the σ-type Ag–C bond between the terminal carbon atom C1 of the ethynide moiety and its approximately collinear silver atom Ag (∠C2C1–Ag (θ) range set to be 160–180°) is much shorter than other Ag–C bonds. The π-type bonds, which are taken to be those with C2C1–Ag angles less than 90°, are generally the longest among all Ag–C bonds, whereas the remaining mixed (σ,π)-type bonds correspond to those with C2C1–Ag angles lying between a right angle and 160°.

[AgCCCH<sub>2</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>CCAg]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>

The title compound is hereafter abbreviated as Ag2C6H4. Silver nitrate (0.680 g, 4 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of acetonitrile. Then 1,5-hexadiyne (0.156, 2 mmol) was added with vigorous stirring for 1 h. The white precipitate tha tformed was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with 3 × 10 mL of acetonitrile and 3 × 10 mL of deionized water to remove traces of nitric acid, and stored in a wet form for safety reasons. Yield: 0.478 g (82%).

Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub> <bold>·</bold>7AgNO<sub>3</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Moist Ag2C6H4 (∼100 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgNO3 (0.44 g, 2 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution reached saturation. The excess Ag2C6H4 was filtered off, and the solution was then placed in the dark at room temperature. After a few days, transparent colorless sheetlike crystals of 1 (∼75%) were deposited and collected. Compound 1 decomposes above 185 °C. IR: ν 2091 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C6H4Ag9N7O21 (M r = 1480.99): C, 4.87; H, 0.27, N; 6.62. Found: C, 4.51; H, 0.54; N, 6.48.

Moist Ag2C6H4 (∼100 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgNO3 (0.44 g, 2 mmol) and AgF (0.127, 1 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution reached saturation. The excess Ag2C6H4 was filtered off, and the solution was then placed in the dark at room temperature. After a few days, transparent brown platelike crystals of 2 (∼55%) were deposited and collected. Compound 2 decomposes above 130 °C. IR: ν 2063 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C6H4Ag7F2N3O9 (M r = 1055.21): C, 6.83; H, 0.38; N, 3.98. Found: C, 6.81; H, 0.65; N, 4.19.
